title: IU would accept NIT bid
text:
IU would accept NIT bid Zach Osterman , zach.osterman@indystar.com Published 4:06 p.m. ET Feb. 16, 2017 | Updated 13 minutes ago Buy Photo Indiana Hoosiers head coach Tom Crean calls out to his players in the second half of their game Saturday, December 31, 2016, afternoon at Bankers Life Fieldhouse. The Indiana Hoosiers lost to the Louisville Cardinals 77-62. (Photo: Matt Kryger/IndyStar) Buy Photo CONNECT COMMENT EMAIL MORE 
BLOOMINGTON­­ — Provided Indiana’s fading NCAA tournament hopes are not revived, the Hoosiers plan to accept an NIT bid next month, if invited. 
Senior associate athletic director Jeremy Gray confirmed to IndyStar on Thursday that IU has received an NIT-specific contract from the NCAA and intends to return it by the March 6 deadline. 
The NCAA, which oversees the NIT, distributes contracts to potential NIT entrants starting in late January. 
Automatically voided if any such team manages to secure an NCAA tournament bid, the contract binds the program to accepting an NIT bid if offered, according to David Worlock, NCAA director of media coordination/statistics. 
Worlock said teams may decline to sign the contract and still participate in the NIT should they later signal their interest, and that the contract is designed, in part, to ensure teams who sign it don’t decline NIT participation in favor of another non-NCAA postseason tournament. But signing the contract obliges participation, if selected. 
NIT participation is not compulsory, and teams have elected to decline invitations in the recent past. Perhaps most notably, LSU chose not to play in the annual postseason tournament last March, after the Tigers — anchored by eventual No. 1 overall NBA draft pick Ben Simmons — failed to earn a place in the NCAA field. 
Indiana, however, intends to be involved, if invited. 
Bracket projections for the second-tier competition are not as common as NCAA tournament forecasts. But two websites, DRatings.com and NYC Buckets, both currently project the Hoosiers as a No. 1 seed in the NIT field. Both forecasts were published before Wednesday’s loss to Minnesota. 
The Hoosiers have not appeared in the NIT since 2005, when they lost a first-round home game against Vanderbilt. The last time Indiana was eligible for the NIT but not selected to the NCAA tournament field, in 2013-14, the Hoosiers finished the season 17-15 and did not receive a bid. 
Following the conclusion of that season, Indiana declined to play in any tertiary postseason tournaments, like the College Basketball Invitational.
